species_list: Acer, Betula, Fagus, Fraxinus, Liriodendron, Prunus, Quercus
rep_number: 440 total; n = 119 trees from 2011 to 2020 for HF; 321 trees from 1998 to 2003
gsl_metric: climate related to satellite phenology data
gs_start_metric: Tmax during CTW (window of spring time)
teststatistic_where: Fig 1. Found weak and inconsistent relationships between Tmax during CTW (window of spring time) and change in DBH and max growth
ifyouthink_no_why: I agree with their no, but they use weird metrics and do not directly link their phenology and growth
ourdefinition_evidence_gslxgrowth: not tested but have data (satellite phenology)
excellent_study: Sadly no, because they never actually test the GSL to growth link.
missing_something_major: Did not correlate phenology and growth; correlated something like spring phenology sensitivity (they call it CTW, see bottom right pg 554) with growth (multiple metrics)

species_list: Acer, Betula, Carya, Fagus, Fraxinus, Liriodendron, Magnolia, Nyssa, Populus, Quercus
excellent_study: See other row of data for this paper
notes: This is followup to their phenology x dendrometer part of the paper, they used tree rings to look at lots of correlations.

study_level: within individuals for < 1 year (April to October 2018)
notes: More data people; but This one was really interesting because they looked at cell number and cell size of early and late wood formation and came to the conclusion that longer growing season means increased number of cells, but not increased biomass

study_level: within individuals for < 1 year (April to October 2018)

species_list: Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris, Abies alba, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Quercus petraea, Quercus pubesence
gs_metric_other: start of growth, end of growth
ifyouthink_no_why: agree with authors that they do not see a relationship (Fig 4 shows no relationship with SOS, EOS or GSL)
excellent_study: They directly looked at growth X gsl
big_problems: Using the number of growing days to look at growth seems weird to mee (I remember folks talking about it during previous group meetings, but now it makes sense and I agree that it's weird)

species_list: Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris, Abies alba, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Quercus petraea, Quercus pubesence
excellent_study: They directly looked at growth X gsl
big_problems: Using the number of growing days to look at growth seems weird to mee (I remember folks talking about it during previous group meetings, but now it makes sense and I agree that it's weird)

study_scale: 16 open top chambers with two 2-year old saplings each
rep_number: 4 chambers per treatment, 24 trees per species
growth_metric: modelled carbon uptake (SPAC); as well as components of photosynthesis that went into (A_tot) and stomatal conductance
teststatistic_where: Fig 3 (but see also text and Fig 4)
big_problems: modeled carbon, no other growth metric beyond messy height and DBH
notes_specific_columns: authorslooked_endogenousfactors; not sure if Fig 4 relates to what we might call endogenous

gsl_metric: all days with an average daily temperature above DTMIN
authorsthink_teststatistic: model output of treeline allowed them to estimate the number of suitable days needed for growth for this species; no real tests
authorsfoundevidencefor_externalfactors_: not clear what would constitute evidence or not
notes: model on tree line, not related to growth

species_list: Fagus sylvatica, Quercus petreaea, Pinus sylvestris
study_scale: one site (Fontainebleu) 15 trees, 3 per species in one experimental forest
excellent_study: They compare veg phenology with wood phenology also.
notes: they also kind of looked at carbon allocation at different dates a little bit (NSC analysis)

species_list: Fagus sylvatica, Quercus petreaea, Pinus sylvestris
study_scale: one site (Fontainebleu) 15 trees, 3 per species in one experimental forest
ifyouthink_no_why: pg 1040 stats, I agree with authors
